title: Key Performance Indicators
text: (KPIs) are a performance measurement of a particular activity that a team member performs. In essence, KPIs measure a team member’s individual contribution to TLC’s overall goals and strategies. Thus, KPIs determine your incentive pay or performance bonus pay. KPIs are calculated for each pay period as a per hour bonus that is added to the hourly base pay wage for every hour worked during the pay period. Current KPIs are always posted on each CCM’s Dashboard. Each KPI will include the following information: the minimum acceptable performance level (the performance level that “meets expectations”); the individual KPI percentage of total incentive pay; the maximum KPI incentive amount; and, the timeframe for each KPI incentive availability. title: Last Resort
text: are almost always sufficient to de-escalate and resolve those situations. On very, very rare occasions, we interact with individuals who have no interest in resolving hard situations or listening to polite but firm calls for civility. While we strive for the highest service standards, you must also know that you are empowered to

title: Stand Up
text: in those situations as follows: 80 1) Quickly recognize those situations that are abusive, harassing or intentionally futile. This recognition is solely up to your own judgment. While this is most often done by recognizing an abusive, harassing, or wasteful pattern developing, we trust your ability to recognize the difference between a frustrated client and an abusive individual. 2) Immediately end the call—do not continue to engage with the individual. Repeated attempts at civility sometimes just encourage bad actors to continue their bad behavior. 3) Document the situation in writing. Document the call in the LMS. Copy and paste that documentation in an email to your immediate supervisor. They will take appropriate steps to stop all contact with that individual. And, when appropriate, contact legal counsel and public safety representatives.

title: Advanced Client Issues
text: may arise while working with a client. These issues include complaints, disputes, attorney communications, bankruptcy statements, etc. The steps to report and resolve client issues are outlined below. As you receive communication from a client, a client’s attorney, or a regulatory body on behalf of a client, look for the following: ● Complaint: A complaint is received from an attorney or regulatory agency. ● Fraud or Dispute of Debt: A client disputes that they took, or applied for, a loan. ● Regulatory: A notification received from a regulatory agency. ● Military: A notification was received proving the client is in active military service. ● OFAC: A formal notification that would come from the office of foreign assets control. ● Cease and Desist: A statement of cease and desist. ● Deceased: Received notification that the client has passed away. ● Bankruptcy: A client has indicated that they have filed for Bankruptcy, or they have sent any of the following info: Bankruptcy Lawyer’s Name, Lawyer’s Phone Number, Case #, Chapter #, or Date Filed. ● Debt Consolidation: POA is received from an attorney with indication of debt consolidation.
